docs.lead_paragraph: In an article a few years ago in The Journal of the American Medical Association, Dr. Barbara Starfield of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine took a look at the overall health of the American people, and compared conditions here to those in other industrialized countries. What she found was disturbing.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says Dr Barbara Starfield, writing in Journal of the American Medical Assn in 2000, found that United States ranks 12th of 13 nations studied for 16 available health indicators; says US has most expensive health care system in world, but millions of Americans without access to care die from illnesses that could have been successfully treated if diagnosed in time; says Starfield says situation has worsened since 2000; she calls for coverage for many millions who have no access to care, and development of first-rate primary care system; Herbert notes that elected officials give lip service to health care issues only while they are campaigning for office (M)
docs.snippet: In an article a few years ago in The Journal of the American Medical Association, Dr. Barbara Starfield of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine took a look at the overall health of the American people, and compared conditions here to those in other...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN

docs.lead_paragraph: Teresa Marie Ashley was married last evening to Richard Simon Basile. Pastor Ronald H. Naff, a Disciples of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the First Christian Church in Longview, Wash. Mrs. Basile, 34, is a consultant to doctors on malpractice insurance for NCRIC, a health care financial services company in Washington. She graduated magna cum laude from Seattle University and received a law degree from Gonzaga University in Spokane, Wash. She is the daughter of Alice and Clifford Ashley of Longview. Her father is a retired carpenter and independent contractor in Longview. Her mother works in Longview as an executive assistant in charge of employee scheduling at the Weyerhaeuser Company, the wood products maker.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding your June 23 editorial ''A Blow to Health Plan Patients,'' about a recent Supreme Court ruling: The matter of patient lawsuits against health care providers is just one of many problems plaguing our so-called health care system that would be greatly alleviated by adopting a national health plan.
docs.abstract: Franklin C Southworth letter responds to June 23 editorial; contends that matter of patient lawsuits against health care providers is just one of many problems that would be alleviated by adopting national health plan

docs.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Credit Suisse Group denied on Friday that the company had abandoned its ambitions as a global bank and said instead that Credit Suisse intended to grow by making its core banking business more competitive before it considered major foreign acquisitions. Walter B. Kielholz, the chairman of the group, said in a telephone interview that the company had a ''specific mix'' of businesses, some global like its private bank and its investment banking unit, and some largely confined to its home base of Switzerland, like retail banking.

headline.main: Chief Insists Credit Suisse Still Has Global Ambitions

docs.abstract: Walter B Kielholz, chairman of Credit Suisse Group, denies that company has abandoned its ambitions as global bank and says it intends to grow by making its core banking business more competitive before it considers major foreign acquisitions; says company has specific mix of businesses, some global like its private bank and its investment banking unit, and some largely confined to its home base of Switzerland, like retail banking; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Conciliatory Koreas Pose Issues for Washington South Korea's conciliatory stance toward North Korea -- it is North Korea's largest source of aid, trade and tourism and its most consistent diplomatic advocate -- is causing unease in Washington. The White House, South Korea and Japan are trying to induce North Korea to drop its nuclear weapons program. A1 A senior Bush administration official, speaking from the nuclear talks in Beijing, said that the United States and North Korea had made little headway in resolving their standoff, but intended to keep trying. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: If you hear something enough times from people in authority, you tend to believe it. The tort reform zealots -- including doctors, insurance company executives and legions of politicians across the country -- have been hammering away at the idea that crackpot jury awards and lawsuits from undeserving patients are driving up the costs of health care and driving good doctors out of their profession.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says disinformation campaign of tort reform zealots, and their sustained attacks on rights of patients who have been harmed by doctors, has been disgraceful; says several states specifically characterized by American Medical Assn as in 'crisis' as result of malpractice claims and awards are actually experiencing record lows in such suits; says malpractice insurance premiums have increased sharply not only because of cost of malpractice awards but also because of factors such as decreases in investment income of insurance companies and cyclical factors in insurance market (M)
docs.snippet: If you hear something enough times from people in authority, you tend to believe it.    The tort reform zealots -- including doctors, insurance company executives and legions of politicians across the country -- have been hammering away at the idea...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Kerry has yet to produce a popular catchphrase for his political philosophy, like Gov. Bill Clinton's 1992 promise of a ''third way'' or Gov. George W. Bush's pledge in 2000 of ''compassionate conservatism.'' But Mr. Kerry's Democratic message for the general election campaign is emerging, many Democrats say -- on the campaign trail, in the party platform now being written and in the major speeches he has delivered in recent weeks.

headline.main: Kerry Message Begins Leaning Toward Center

docs.abstract: Many Democrats say Sen John Kerry's message for general election campaign is promise of return to Clintonian centrism; cite his calls to reduce budget, spur economic growth and try to ease what he calls squeeze on middle-class America from cost of items including health insurance and college tuition; familiar faces from Clinton years are now at Kerry's side, including James P Rubin and Gene Sperling; Kerry's message also reflects very different time from 1990's, framed by three unsettling years of terrorism, war and political division; his favorite refrain, plea to 'let America be America again,' is quotation he uses to evoke idea of restoration--for economy, for tax code, for dreams of middle class and for country's foreign policy (M)
docs.snippet: Senator John Kerry has yet to produce a popular catchphrase for his political philosophy, like Gov. Bill Clinton's 1992 promise of a ''third way'' or Gov. George W. Bush's pledge in 2000 of ''compassionate conservatism.''    But Mr. Kerry's...

docs.lead_paragraph: Until a few months ago, Gilles Duceppe was a shaky leader of the fading separatist movement in Quebec, seemingly destined to be an odd footnote in Canadian history. But in an turn of fortunes that has more to do with the collapse of the governing Liberal Party than his own skills, Mr. Duceppe is emerging as the big winner of the parliamentary election campaign that will choose a new prime minister on Monday.
docs.abstract: Gilles Duceppe, leader of fading separatist movement in Quebec, is emerging as big winner of parliamentary election campaign that will choose new prime minister of Canada; he has no chance of replacing Prime Min Paul Martin because his party is competing just in Quebec, but widesrepad disgust there over Liberals' scandals is expected to give his party large delegation to next House of Commons; recent polls show his bloc will emerge for first time as vital power broker in Ottawa; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Until a few months ago, Gilles Duceppe was a shaky leader of the fading separatist movement in Quebec, seemingly destined to be an odd footnote in Canadian history.    But in an turn of fortunes that has more to do with the collapse of the governing...

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress proclaimed Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo the winner in the May 10 presidential election, ending a bitter debate that divided the country. The political opposition insisted that Mrs. Arroyo had cheated. This was the first election since the fall of the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos, in 1986, that an incumbent president ran. Under the Constitution, an elected president cannot run again, but Mrs. Arroyo was vice president under President Joseph Estrada, who was driven from office in 2001, and completed his term. Her opponents said she used her incumbency to spend billions in government money to influence voting by giving out rice and health insurance cards, among other things. The administration denied the accusation. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Arroyo Declared President

docs.abstract: Philippine's Congress declares Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo winner of May 10 presidential election despite protests that her candidacy violated constitutional law that elected president cannot run again; Arroyo became president after President Joseph Estrada was driven from office in 2001 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Frivolous lawsuits and astronomical jury awards are driving up costs and crippling our health care system. On any given day, 125,000 liability lawsuits choke the system. Yet the vast majority of claims, nearly 70 percent, do not result in any payments to patients. Of those that do go to a jury verdict, more than 80 percent are decided in the doctor's favor.

headline.main: In Court: Doctors, Lawyers and Patients

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr John C Nelson, American Medical Assn, asserts that frivolous lawsuits and astronomical jury awards are driving up costs and crippling health care system; says millions used to defend such suits would be better spent on improving patient safety (June 21 Bob Herbert Op-Ed column)
